head.title: Operando Surface Characterization on Catalytic and Energy Materials from Single Crystals to Nanoparticles | ACS Nano

meta.content: Operando Surface Characterization on Catalytic and Energy Materials from Single Crystals to Nanoparticles

Modern surface science faces two major challenges, a materials gap and a pressure gap. While studies on single crystal surface in ultrahigh vacuum have uncovered the atomic and electronic structures of the surface, the materials and environmental conditions of commercial catalysis are much more complicated, both in the structure of the materials and in the accessible pressure range of analysis instruments. Model systems and operando surface techniques have been developed to bridge these gaps. In this Review, we highlight the current trends in the development of the surface characterization techniques and methodologies in more realistic environments, with emphasis on recent research efforts at the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology. We show principles and applications of the microscopic and spectroscopic surface techniques at ambient pressure that were used for the characterization of atomic structure, electronic structure, charge transport, and the mechanical properties of catalytic and energy materials. Ambient pressure scanning tunneling microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy allow us to observe the surface restructuring that occurs during oxidation, reduction, and catalytic processes. In addition, we introduce the ambient pressure atomic force microscopy that revealed the morphological, mechanical, and charge transport properties that occur during the catalytic and energy conversion processes. Hot electron detection enables the monitoring of catalytic reactions and electronic excitations on the surface. Overall, the information on the nature of catalytic reactions obtained with operando spectroscopic and microscopic techniques may bring breakthroughs in some of the global energy and environmental problems the world is facing.

div.span: SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Modern surface science faces two major challenges, a materials gap and a pressure gap. While studies on single crystal surface in ultrahigh vacuum have uncovered the atomic and electronic structures of the surface, the materials and environmental conditions of commercial catalysis are much more complicated, both in the structure of the materials and in the accessible pressure range of analysis instruments. Model systems and
operando
surface techniques have been developed to bridge these gaps. In this Review, we highlight the current trends in the development of the surface characterization techniques and methodologies in more realistic environments, with emphasis on recent research efforts at the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology. We show principles and applications of the microscopic and spectroscopic surface techniques at ambient pressure that were used for the characterization of atomic structure, electronic structure, charge transport, and the mechanical properties of catalytic and energy materials. Ambient pressure scanning tunneling microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy allow us to observe the surface restructuring that occurs during oxidation, reduction, and catalytic processes. In addition, we introduce the ambient pressure atomic force microscopy that revealed the morphological, mechanical, and charge transport properties that occur during the catalytic and energy conversion processes. Hot electron detection enables the monitoring of catalytic reactions and electronic excitations on the surface. Overall, the information on the nature of catalytic reactions obtained with
operando
spectroscopic and microscopic techniques may bring breakthroughs in some of the global energy and environmental problems the world is facing.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.div:
Chemical reactions occurring on single crystal or nanoparticle surfaces take place in several elementary processes, including adsorption, desorption, and chemical rearrangement. Understanding the rate-limiting steps in these processes is crucial for the development of catalysts with enhanced catalytic performance. Over the past several decades, techniques for modern surface science seeking to uncover the reaction mechanisms on the surface, mostly performed on single crystal surfaces at ultrahigh vacuum (UHV), led the atomic- and molecular-scale understanding of physical and chemical properties of the surface.
(1−6)
However, the materials and environmental conditions prevailing in industrial catalysis are much more complicated. It is therefore important to characterize the surface morphology, electronic structures, and oxidation states under the conditions where the catalysts work.
(7−16)
The various
operando
surface science techniques on the single crystals and nanoparticles are shown in the scheme of
Figure
1
.

div.p:
Figure 1. Scheme of challenges of modern surface science and some techniques for overcoming the structural and environmental complexities of fundamental studies. Several
operando
surface techniques are indicated, including ambient pressure scanning tunneling microscopy (AP-STM), ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (AP-XPS), ambient pressure vibration spectroscopy, environmental transmission electron microscopy (E-TEM), and the catalytic nanodiode.

div.div:
The reaction mechanism of heterogeneous catalysis is often affected by the change of pressure during the reaction. The Gibbs free energy varies with pressure according to the following expression:
(1)
where
k
B
is the Boltzmann constant,
T
is temperature,
p
is the pressure,
p
° is a reference pressure, and
G
° is the Gibbs free energy at the reference pressure. Following this equation, the difference in Gibbs free energy between atmospheric and UHV conditions (≈10
–10
Torr) is about 0.78 eV at room temperature. This difference is large enough to drive reactions that would be unobservable in standard surface science conditions. For example, weakly adsorbed molecules can have a high coverage on the surface in equilibrium with the gas phase at sufficiently high pressure, but in UHV, this can only be achieved by cooling the sample to cryogenic temperatures, which makes the kinetics of the reaction too low to observe. Following the scheme shown in
Figure
2
, at ambient pressure, the structural rearrangement takes place differently compared to the arrangement in a vacuum in order to minimize surface energy. However, industrial catalysts are highly dispersed nanoparticles on porous oxide with high surface area (structural complexities), and the reaction conditions involve pressures near atmospheric values or aqueous conditions (environmental complexities). The development of catalysts, including nanoparticles and nanowires as well as
operando
surface techniques, has been proposed to overcome these challenges.
(11,10,17−19)

div.p: Figure 2. Schemes showing surface restructuring driven by the equilibration with increasing environmental pressure.

div.div:
Here, we highlight recent research activities about
operando
surface science studies on catalytic and energy materials. Ambient pressure scanning tunneling microscopy (AP-STM) and ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (AP-XPS) allow us to observe surface restructuring under oxidation, reduction, and catalytic conditions. As an example, in the
in situ
observation of structural modulation on bimetallic surfaces, from single crystal surfaces to bimetallic nanoparticles, we show that the formation of reactive interface between metal skin and oxide clusters is a general process on the single crystal surface as well as nanoparticles, indicating that this reactive metal–oxide interface is a key element in the enhanced catalytic activity. In addition, we introduce ambient pressure atomic force microscopy (AP-AFM) that revealed morphological, mechanical, and charge transport properties during the catalytic and energy conversion processes. For example, the ambient pressure studies of single crystal perovskite surfaces that reveal the atomic-scale degradation process are shown. Detecting hot electrons enables us to monitor the chemical reactions, making it another
in situ
technique that gives rise to the information on charge transport through the metal–oxide interfaces. Vibration spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques performed under ambient pressure lead to information on chemical bonds and the restructuring of nanoparticle surfaces.

div.h2:
Operando
Surface Science on Single Crystal Catalysts

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3:
Operando
Surface Probes on Single Crystals
div.div:
The development of real-space imaging techniques, often referred to as scanning probe microscopes, such as scanning tunneling microscope and atomic force microscope, had a significant impact on the study of morphology, the electromagnetic and mechanical structures of surfaces at an atomic to nanoscale resolution, with implications in areas varying from device processing to understanding catalytic reactions at an atomic level.
(20,21)
After its invention in 1981 by Binning
et al.
, STM quickly became one of the most important surface science techniques; the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1986, only four years after the publication, exhibits the perceived significance of this technique.
(22,23)
STM, as the name suggests, utilizes electron tunneling between two conducting bodies, namely, the tip and the sample, to obtain the surface topography by probing the local density of states (LDOS). Furthermore, electron tunneling enables STM to probe electron states at different energies at a point or as an image, referred to as scanning tunneling spectroscopy (STS). After almost 40 years, commercially available scanning tunneling microscopes are routinely capable of obtaining a lateral resolution of ≤100 pm and a vertical resolution of 1 pm, which is enough to identify atomic features at the surface.
(24−26)

Understanding chemical reactions at heterogeneous catalysts is one of the most studied topics in surface science. STM is an adequate technique to study catalytic reaction mechanisms in
operando
conditions as its measurement, in principle, is not limited by pressure or temperature. Soon after the invention of STM, many groups successfully performed reliable STM measurements in atmospheric pressure,
(27)
e.g.
, graphite,
(28)
layered materials
(29,30)
and sulfur adatoms on Mo(001).
(31)
While these ambient pressure studies suffer from inevitable surface contamination from air, much of our current understanding of the atomic-level mechanism of the catalytic reactions is based on studies in UHV conditions; these provide efficient sample preparation methods,
i.e.
, ion sputter–annealing and minimum contamination during transfer and measurement, and enable the
in situ
utilization of many other surface science techniques,
e.g.
, Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and low-energy electron diffraction (LEED). In 1992, McIntyre
et al.
constructed the scanning tunneling microscope which was able to measure in pressure from UHV up to atmospheric pressure and at temperatures ranging from 300 to 425 K: the birth of “AP-STM”.
(32,33)

The initial design of the ambient-pressure-compatible STM scanner is similar to their previous UHV STM scanner design,
(34)
but most of the parts were made of aluminum in order to achieve low reactivity from gaseous environments while ensuring excellent thermal conductivity.
Figure
3
a shows a schematic illustration of an AP-STM system. A platinum–rhodium alloy tip was used to achieve high resistivity to oxidation. Tungsten tips, widely used in UHV STM systems, are susceptible to oxidation in high-pressure oxygen or water, which causes the constant change of the tip shape, making it impossible to obtain atomic resolution images. The STM scanner is housed in a 2 L reaction chamber, which is fitted with vacuum pumps (
e.g.
, ion pump and a turbomolecular pump) and leak valves and gauges for gas introduction and control. The system was also equipped with a differentially pumped quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS) for gas analysis during STM measurement. Having the STM scanner and the sample inside the ambient pressure chamber is often referred to as a backfilling type.

div.p: Figure 3. Schematic illustrations of (a) AP-STM, (b) AP-AFM, (c) AP-XPS, and (d) reflection–absorption infrared spectroscopy (RAIRS).

div.div:
Since the initial demonstration of AP-STM, few groups have applied the backfilling principle in order to construct AP-STM for
operando
surface science studies.
(35−38)
However, having both the STM scanner and the sample stage in reaction conditions has some disadvantages, such as limiting the maximum achievable pressure due to the ConFlat sealing mechanism of UHV chamber flanges and limiting sample heating temperature due to heat loss
via
the large volume of reactant gases. A large amount of heat transfer from the catalyst to the AP-STM chamber walls causes desorption of adsorbed molecules, which act as a significant source of surface contamination. After the construction of a small reactor cell (≈19 cm
3
) consisting of the sample stage and the STM scanner within a UHV chamber, which could overcome the aforementioned limitations to some extent,
(39)
Tao
et al.
, through a collaboration with SPECS Surface Nano Analysis GbmH, built an AP scanning tunneling microscope in 2013 that could effectively thermally isolate the scanner piezo components from the hot reactor in order to minimize thermal drift, which was the bottleneck in achieving atomic resolution for AP scanning tunneling microsopes at high temperature in near ambient pressure conditions.
(40)
In this design, the STM scanner was thermally isolated by a small molybdenum dome, through which only the tip can pass a 0.5 nm aperture to probe the catalyst sample surface; atomically resolved STM images could thereby be obtained in pressure up to 1 bar and elevated temperatures up to 700 K. It is also worthwhile to mention the “reactorSTM” design by Herbschleb
et al.
, in which the STM scanner could be separated from the high-pressure reactor cell (0.5 cm
3
) and remain in UHV.
(41)
The AP scanning tunneling microscope in this reactorSTM system could be operated from UHV to 6 bar and at temperatures up to 600 K.

After its invention in 1986,
(42)
AFM quickly became a versatile surface probing technique for the investigation of various surface properties, including topography,
(43−45)
adhesion,
(46,47)
friction,
(48,49)
conductance,
(50−52)
magnetization,
(53)
surface potential,
(54)
and more.
(55,56)
One of the most widely used force detection mechanisms in AFM is the laser deflection method, in which a laser beam is reflected from the back of a cantilever and detected by a position-sensitive photodiode.
(57)
From the position of the reflected beam, one can detect the bending of the cantilever perpendicular (normal force) and parallel (lateral force) to the surface plane. Despite the versatility of AFM, until recently, no attempts had been made to construct an UHV-compatible variable pressure atomic force microscope that can operate in
operando
conditions.

Figure
3
b shows a schematic illustration of the AP-AFM system, which was demonstrated by Choi
et al.
in 2018.
(58)
In this design, a commercially available beetle-type RHK STM/AFM scanner with beam deflection force feedback method
(57)
is utilized to measure topography, friction, and electric conductance simultaneously.
(49,59)
The AP-AFM system uses a simple backfilling method
via
a leak valve connected to a gas manifold to control the pressure of the “ambient pressure” chamber from UHV (≈1 × 10
–10
mbar) to 1 bar. A stable measurement of atomic resolution stick–slip images of highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) from UHV to 1 bar oxygen and back was achieved, exhibiting the low drift of the scanner by the pressure change. From enhanced adhesion force between the AFM tip and clean HOPG in methane compared to oxygen, they show that the significantly increased work of adhesion of air-exposed HOPG comes from airborne hydrocarbon contamination, and how AP-AFM effectively contributes to the studies of the behavior of adhesion and friction in different gaseous environments.

XPS is one of the most versatile spectroscopic methods for studying physical and chemical surface properties, providing nondestructive, element-specific, and quantitative information (for a schematic illustration, see
Figure
3
c).
(60)
The nanometer-scale inelastic mean free path of electrons with kinetic energies < 1500 eV makes XPS a strongly surface-sensitive technique.
(61,62)
Due to the strong interaction of electrons with gas molecules, conventional XPS is only operated under UHV conditions, limiting the application of critical pressure to catalysis.
(63)
The working of XPS is difficult at pressures above 10
–6
Torr. To overcome the pressure limitation of XPS, the traveling distance of electrons in the gaseous region should be minimized. Siegbahn
et al.
, who initially developed the photoelectron spectrometer, constructed XPS for the gas and liquid phase by separating the sample region from the X-ray source by the window and placing the sample surface near the differentially pumped apertures for reducing the travel distance of electrons in the gaseous area.
(64−66)
Although several groups developed the AP-XPS system using DPSs, early AP-XPS instruments were less suited to catalytic surface analysis under reaction conditions, due to the significantly low count rate of detected photoelectrons.
(67−69)
In 2002, the AP-XPS design was developed by a group at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.
(70)
They enhanced the low count rate of early AP-XPS by using high-flux synchrotron radiation as a light source and minimized the loss of photoelectron signal under high pressures by combining the differential pumping with the electrostatic lens system. The ejected photoelectrons in this system are captured at the front nozzle, which is connected to the differential pumping stages. The electrostatic lenses in the differential pumping stage focus the electrons to the sample plane of the hemispherical analyzer, as shown in
Figure
3
c. Using these differentially pumped electrostatic lens systems, their AP-XPS could operate at up to 100 mbar. After that, many synchrotrons around the world installed AP-XPS instruments with differentially pumped electrostatic lens systems, including ALBA in Spain, SOLEIL in France, Photon Factory in Japan,
(71)
and MAX-lab in Sweden.
(72)
Synchrotron-based AP-XPS instruments with dramatically high photon flux have been utilized for investigating the surface of transition metals,
(73−75)
Pt-based bimetals,
(76−78)
and metal oxide single crystals.
(79,80)

Reflection adsorption infrared spectroscopy (RAIRS) is also a powerful technique for studying the surface of single crystal catalysts under realistic conditions (for schematic illustration, see
Figure
3
d). Mainly, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) is specialized to provide information about the chemical identity and binding strength of gas molecules adsorbed on the surface and that of the intermediate species produced during catalysis.
(81,82)
In FTIR, the infrared (IR) beam is reflected at the sample surface before collection. RAIRS is specialized to surface-sensitive investigations of solid–gas and solid–liquid interfaces at pressures from UHV to
operando
conditions.
(83)
The intensity of the signal is particularly weak, due to the small area of the surface where the IR beam is reflected. The weak signal of RAIRS can be enhanced by polarization modulation IR reflection absorption spectroscopy (PM-IRRAS), which can distinguish adsorbed species and gas phase species.
(84,85)
The infrared reflection absorption spectroscopy (IRRAS) can be utilized for mechanistic study of chemical reactions by probing chemical properties of adsorbed intermediate molecules produced under the reaction conditions.
(86,87)
Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFT) is a FTIR technique that is effective for studying powder samples.
(88)
The sample placed in a basket is illuminated by the focused infrared beam, and the scattered light is collected with a parabolic mirror for detection.
Operando
studies of DRIFT are also possible by combining mass spectrometry or gas chromatography, which can give information about the catalytic performance and the chemical properties of adsorbed species simultaneously.

div.h3: Ambient Pressure STM and XPS Studies on Transition Metal Surfaces
div.div:
Carbon monoxide adsorption on transition metal surfaces, such as platinum, is one of the most important topics in catalytic reaction studies.
(5,6)
Extensive studies have been conducted to understand the adsorption of CO on Pt(111) as a model system for Pt-based catalysts. In UHV and low-temperature investigations, many commensurate adsorption superstructures are observed and thoroughly identified.
(92−94)
However, in 1996, a vibrational spectrum of CO on Pt(111) over a pressure range (UHV to 700 Torr) from sum frequency generation (SFG) measurement suggested different CO adsorption configurations in more realistic conditions.
(95)
A few years later, Somorjai and co-workers successfully obtained AP-STM images of Pt(111) in the high pressure of CO,
i.e.
, up to 750 Torr.
(89,96)
Exposure to high-pressure CO, unlike some other species,
e.g.
, sulfur,
(97)
did not alter the shape of the steps of Pt(111).
Figure
4
a shows an STM image of Pt(111) in 550 Torr of CO; a reversible formation of a hexagonal moiré superstructure was observed at the terrace when CO pressure was above approximately 100 Torr.
(89)
The moiré superstructure was analyzed in greater detail by Longwits
et al.
, where they identified the commensurate and incommensurate
–13CO moiré superstructure, which is also observed at low-pressure and -temperature conditions (170 K).
(98)
The CO superstructure undergoes rotational transition as the CO pressure increases and coverage increases from 0.5 to 0.7 monolayer (ML) with respect to the Pt(111) substrate. This behavior is explained in terms of the repulsive lateral CO–CO interaction dominating the corrugation effect from the substrate interaction potential.
(99)

div.p:
Figure 4. Ambient pressure studies on Pt single crystals. (a) STM image (250 × 250 Å
2
) of Pt(111) in 550 Torr CO. The corrugation at the terrace is the moiré pattern of CO overlayer on Pt substrate. Reprinted with permission from ref
(89)
. Copyright 1999 Springer Nature. The STM images of (b) disordered and (c) ordered superstructures of Pt(111) in 10.5 Torr of mixed CO/O
2
gas (1:3 ratio). Reprinted with permission from ref
(90)
. Copyright 2018 American Chemical Society. STM images (40 × 50 nm
2
) of stepped Pt(557) at (d) UHV, (e) 5 × 10
–8
Torr CO, and (f) 1 Torr CO and (g) the close-up image of panel f. AP-XPS spectra of (h) Pt 4f and (i) O 1s. Reprinted with permission from ref
(91)
. Copyright 2010 American Association for the Advancement of Science.

div.div:
The strong adsorption of CO species on catalyst surfaces often works against desired catalytic reactions, referred to as CO catalyst poisoning. Adsorption of a trace of CO in the reactant gas could poison various catalytic reactions at the surface of Pt(111). Hydrogenation/dehydrogenation reactions of cyclohexene and cyclohexane are completely suppressed by adding 5 mTorr of CO in the reactant gas, and a stable ordered CO overlayer structure was observed in AP-STM.
(100)
In a similar mechanism, 5 mTorr of CO also poisons the hydrogen/deuterium exchange reaction on Pt(111). AP-STM and AP-XPS clearly show ordered CO overlayer formation, which, as a result, completely suppresses the H
2
/D
2
exchange reaction. Interestingly, the catalytic activity of Pt(111) is enhanced, and CO poisoning is weakened in the presence of oxygen, because the chemisorption of oxygen on the Pt surface provides favorable active sites for reactant molecules.
(101,102)
Kim
et al.
explain these phenomena by competitive molecular adsorption of CO and O
2
on Pt(111) surface at room temperature by AP-STM.
(90)
Panels b and c of
Figure
4
show AP-STM images of Pt(111) in 10.5 Torr of mixed CO/O
2
gas (1:3 ratio). At 300 K, the disordered CO overlayer (
Figure
4
b) and ordered commensurate CO overlayer (
Figure
4
c) structures, which resemble a pure CO adsorbed overlayer moiré pattern (
e.g.
,
Figure
4
a), actively coexist. Consecutive AP-STM measurements in the time scale of 1300 s provided a library of dynamic formation of surface overlayers of CO and O
2
, which shows that the competitive adsorption of CO and O
2
elucidates the possible catalytic reaction mechanisms for CO oxidation on Pt catalyst surfaces.
(103)

Unlike single crystal model systems such as Pt(111), industrial catalysts exhibit a high concentration of catalytically active sites,
e.g.
, step edges, kink sites, and vacancies.
(5,6)
Stepped single crystal surfaces provide a well-defined model system for the high density of the active sites of the industrial catalysts. Pt(557) and Pt(337) were employed to study the effect of CO on the structure of real catalysts.
(91)
Panels d–f of
Figure
4
show STM images of Pt(557) in UHV, in 5 × 10
–8
Torr of CO, and in 1 Torr of CO, respectively. Interestingly, Pt morphology dramatically changed depending on CO pressure. At moderate pressure of CO (
Figure
4
e), the step density decreased and the step height increased by a factor of 2 with respect to UHV condition (
Figure
4
d). At high pressures of CO (
Figure
4
f) formation of ≈2.1 nm size, triangular-shaped nanoclusters are observed (
Figures
4
f,g). In AP-XPS spectra, a reversible increase of Pt 4f 72.15 eV component (
Figure
4
h), which is attributed to low-coordinated Pt atoms, and O 1s 532.7 eV component (
Figure
4
i), which is attributed to CO bonded to the top site, is observed. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the restructuring of the steps is due to the high coverage of CO, which would exert strong repulsion between adsorbed CO molecules. The breakup of the surface structure is caused by the relaxation of the repulsive CO–CO interaction. In the recent study by Kim
et al.
, the strong CO–CO repulsion is also found to cause further surface reconstruction to the ordered nanocluster structure of Pt(557) in high-pressure CO at elevated temperature.
(104)

AP-STM study of Pt(110) showed the modification of the surface structure and composition under
operando
conditions.
(105)
The upper part of
Figure
5
shows the QCM measurements of CO, O
2
, and CO
2
partial pressures during the CO oxidation reaction at Pt(110) at 425 K, while the lower part shows the representative STM images at different stages indicated in the partial pressure plot. Monoatomic steps and large terraces are observed during the initial stage of the reaction where only CO was exposed to the surface (
Figure
5
a). As O
2
partial pressure increased, CO pressure decreased steadily, but no change in the surface morphology was observed (
Figure
5
b) until CO pressure drops below a threshold value, marked as
P
th
. As CO pressure reaches
P
th
, a sudden increase of reactivity,
i.e.
, CO
2
conversion, is observed together with the increased surface roughness from the formation of Pt oxide clusters (
Figure
5
c,d). When the gas flow is switched back to CO-rich conditions, CO
2
and O
2
decrease slowly and the surface morphology is restored (
Figure
5
e). As the O
2
pressure is increased (
Figure
5
f), the same trend of sudden increase of CO oxidation reaction below
P
th
and the formation of Pt oxide formation (
Figure
5
g) is observed. When O
2
is removed again, the Pt adatom and vacancy islands were observable (
Figure
5
h). The CO oxidation reaction is most active when surface oxide clusters form,
e.g.
,
Figure
5
d,g, indicating that the surface morphology and the formation of surface oxides can significantly affect the catalytic activity of transition metal catalysts in the actual reaction conditions.

div.p:
Figure 5. (Top) Changes in the partial pressure of oxygen, carbon monoxide, and carbon dioxide with respect to the elapsed time during the CO oxidation reaction at Pt(110) surface. (Bottom) AP-STM images (200 × 200 nm
2
) at the selected reaction conditions. The CO/O
2
mixed gas flow rate is 3.0 mL/min at 0.5 bar; the surface temperature of Pt(110) is 425 K. Reprinted with permission from ref
(105)

div.h3: Ambient Pressure STM and XPS Studies on Pt-Based Bimetal Surfaces
div.div:
Platinum-based 3d transition metal bimetallic alloys exhibit peculiar surface electronic structures due to the shift of the d-band center near the Fermi level, which provide promising candidates for efficient heterogeneous catalysts.
(76,106−108)
In particular, Pt–Ni and Pt–Co exhibit exceptional catalytic reactivity in oxygen reduction and CO oxidation reactions.
(109−111)
Fundamental material characterization of the model bimetallic catalysts using UHV-based surface science methods provides basic information on the materials. However, the ambient pressure characterization is essential for the full understanding of the molecular interactions in
operando
conditions, which induce surface restructuring.
(112,113)
Here, we discuss surface restructuring and the consequent effects in catalytic reaction mechanisms reported in recent AP-STM and AP-XPS investigations.

Combined AP-STM and AP-XPS reveal adsorption and catalytic reaction mechanisms of bimetallic catalysts. Kim
et al.
investigated Pt
3
Ni alloy with AP-STM and AP-XPS under CO oxidation reaction conditions.
(114,115)
Annealing Pt
3
Ni(111) at 1100 K forms a single topmost Pt-skin layer (
Figure
6
a), showing lattice geometry similar to Pt(111). However, the electronic surface structure differs significantly from Pt(111).
(116)
As a result, exposure to 120 mTorr of CO induces molecular adsorption of CO (
Figure
6
b), without the moiré superstructure observed in Pt(111) surfaces.
(99)
Exposure to 135 mTorr of pure oxygen (
Figure
6
c) and 120 mTorr of mixed CO/O
2
at 1:5 ratio (
Figure
6
d) cause surface restructuring and formation of nickel oxide nanostructures by dissociative oxygen adsorption, while mixed CO/O
2
exposure only prompts the spontaneous segregation of partially oxidized Ni oxide clusters. Such Ni oxide nanoclusters are observed to be mobile in CO oxidation reaction conditions; panels e–g of
Figure
6
exhibit the unstable Ni oxide particles (marked by red arrows). The instability of the Ni oxide nanoparticles is caused by chemical reactions at the metal–oxide interfaces. Indeed, the AP-XPS spectra of Pt 4f and Ni 2p in the reaction conditions (
Figure
6
h) show a Pt–CO core level shift and broad Ni oxide components. O 1s spectra in elevated temperature (
Figure
6
i) indicate Ni oxide formation at 393 K and a complete CO oxidation at 543 K. AP-XPS results show molecular CO adsorption to Pt atoms and Ni oxide formation, suggesting CO oxidation reaction from molecular CO adsorbed to Pt and dissociative adsorption of oxygen at Ni oxide nanoclusters. Also, CO poisoning of Pt catalysts can be suppressed by incorporating Ni components, demonstrating the superior turnover rates observed compared to single metal Pt or Ni catalysts.
(110,117)

div.p:
Figure 6. AP-STM and AP-XPS studies on Pt–Ni alloy. STM images of Pt
3
Ni(111) (a) after UHV preparation, (b) in 120 mTorr of CO, (c) 135 mTorr of O
2
, and (d) 120 mTorr of mixed CO/O
2
(1:5). Time-dependent Pt
3
Ni(111) STM images in 120 mTorr of CO/O
2
(1:5) at (e) 0, (f) 54 s, and (g) 108 s. (h) Ni 2p and Pt 4f XPS spectra at UHV and 100 mTorr of mixed CO/O
2
(1:5) and (i) O 1s spectra at 140 mTorr of mixed CO/O
2
(1:2.5) and elevated temperatures. Reprinted with permission from ref
(114)
. Copyright 2018 American Association for the Advancement of Science.

div.div:
Platinum–cobalt bimetal catalysts exhibit enhanced catalytic activity and stability for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) compared to single metal Pt catalysts.
(111)
A molecular-level understanding of the oxidation/reduction reactions at the interface and the degradation process for bimetallic catalysts require
in situ operando
surface characterization.
Figure
7
a shows Pt
3
Co(111) surface prepared in UHV condition by the sputter–annealing process. Sample flush annealing at 1100 K formed a single Pt-skin layer at the surface (
Figure
7
a), similar to Pt
3
Ni(111).
(114,119)
In
Figure
7
b, the STM image in dry oxidation conditions (0.1 Torr of N
2
/O
2
(1:1 ratio) at 460 K) shows bright nanoislands (indicated by arrows) and dark pits, which resemble CoO islands in the oxidized Co/Au(111). Interestingly, the surface morphology during the oxidation process differs significantly with the presence of water. In humid O
2
conditions (0.1 Torr of H
2
O/O
2
(1:1 ratio)), cobalt oxide nanoclusters form at the terraces at 370 K
via
Co segregation through the Pt-skin layer (
Figure
7
c), which is activated by a dissociative adsorption of oxygen. At temperatures above 400 K, the surface morphology begins to exhibit further reconstruction of broken multilayer oxides.
Figure
7
d shows the moiré superstructure of O/Co/Pt.
(120)
At 480 K, continuous fully covered oxide multilayer is observed. Synchrotron XPS measurements were conducted to understand the charge transfer and chemical analysis of the observed morphology change in humid oxidation conditions. Co 2p, Pt 4f, and O 1s core-level spectra are observed in (2 × 10
–6
Torr of H
2
O/O
2
(1:1 ratio) at elevated temperature. As the temperature increased from room temperature (RT) to 600 K, a shift from metallic Co, denoted as Co
0
, to oxidation state (Co
2+
) is observed, indicating selective oxidation of Co to Co oxides/hydroxides under humid oxidation conditions (
Figure
7
e).
Figure
7
f shows the development of O 1s spectra at elevated temperatures. Above 400 K, the adsorbed -OH groups are consumed to be transformed into the intermediate CoOOH, showing an enhanced Co(OH)
2
peak, which indicates a predominant ultrathin CoO/Co(OH)
2
overlayer by hydroxylation reaction on the surface.

3
Co(111) (a) after UHV preparation, and 0.1 Torr of (b) dry O
2

div.h3: Ambient Pressure Surface Studies on Metal Oxides
div.div:
Metal oxides and metal–oxide interfaces are crucial factors in determining the properties and performances of heterogeneous catalysts.
(122−124)
The interaction between oxide support and the metallic nanoparticles induces significant changes in their chemical and physical properties, which affects the adsorption and reaction mechanisms of the reactants at the surface.
(125−127)
One example is the enhanced catalytic activities of metal catalysts on oxide supports, which is often referred to as strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) effect.
(128−130)
Although most of the atomic-scale surface science studies on the metal–oxide interfaces and the origin and the mechanism of SMSI effect are carried out in UHV conditions with single crystal model systems, the pressure and materials gap to the industrial catalysts induces significant changes in the reaction mechanisms. Ambient pressure surface studies are therefore crucial to understanding the catalytic reaction mechanisms at the metal–oxide interfaces and the oxide surfaces on the atomic scale in more realistic conditions,
(131,132)
e.g.
, Rh/TiO
2
,
(133)
CeO
x
/Cu(111),
(74,121)
Cu/TiO
2
,
(134)
and MnO
x
/Co.
(135)

Graciani
et al.
found the active sites for CO
2
hydrogenation reaction by combining the
in situ
IRRAS and AP-XPS measurements.
(121)
Figure
8
a shows the catalytic activity of Cu/CeO
x
catalysts on the methanol synthesis reaction. The catalytic activity of CeO
x
/Cu(111) for methanol synthesis is much higher than that of Cu(111) and Cu/ZnO(000
1
). The enhanced catalytic activity of ceria nanoparticles in contact with Cu(111) is due to the dynamic oxidation states of cerium cations in the oxide islands. Panels b and c of
Figure
8
show STM images of as-prepared CeO
2
/Cu
2
O/Cu(111) by vapor deposition of Ce onto Cu(111) in oxygen environment and after 26 h exposure of 1.5 Torr of H
2
. Surface Cu
2
O and single layer ceria islands in
Figure
8
b are reduced in hydrogen atmosphere, leaving CeO
x
/Cu(111) with oxygen vacancies in ceria (indicated in
Figure
8
c). AP-IRRAS and AP-XPS studies were carried out for investigating the intermediate species at the Cu–Ce interfacial sites during the methanol synthesis reaction. The characteristic IRRAS peaks of carboxylate (CO
2
δ−
, 1295 cm
–1
) and formate (HCOO
–
, 1300, 1370, 1598, and 2850 cm
–1
) were observed in the presence of CO
2
and H
2
at 500 K in
Figure
8
d. The AP-XPS spectra for CeO
x
/Cu(111) in
Figure
8
e also show the characteristic peak of carboxylate at 289.2 eV and formate intermediate species at 288.4 eV under the reaction condition at 473 K. They suggested that the carboxylate intermediate species adsorbed on the interfacial sites of CeO
x
and Cu(111) are more active and a completely different type of active site for CO
2
activation by combining the
in situ
IRRAS and AP-XPS investigations.

div.div:
Ambient pressure surface probing techniques can be utilized for studying environmentally sensitive materials as well as catalytic reaction mechanism studies. Organic–inorganic hybrid perovskites find application in next-generation photovoltaic power generation and perovskite-based solar cells (PSCs), show fascinating power conversion efficiency.
(136−139)
However, the commercialization of PSCs is limited due to the instability of the hybrid perovskites. Hybrid perovskites are known to degrade by many factors
(140)
including moisture,
(141)
oxygen,
(142)
light,
(143)
and temperature.
(144)
However, the molecular-level degradation mechanism remains speculative, due to the lack of direct atomic-scale characterization of the degradation process. In 2019, AP-AFM was utilized to study the degradation process of methylammonium lead tribromide (MAPbBr
3
) single crystal, which is a suitable model system for hybrid perovskites.
(145)
The sample was cleaved in the UHV chamber in order to prepare a flat terrace without the exposure to air.
(146,147)
Panels a and b of
Figure
9
show prepared MAPbBr
3
surface morphologies after 7 and 22 days from the cleavage in the UHV chamber; an increase in the number and size of the degraded clusters is observed in the images. The coverage of the degraded clusters with respect to the storage time in the chamber is shown in
Figure
9
c. The degraded clusters exhibit hexagonal symmetry in their shape (
e.g.
,
Figure
9
d), suggesting PbBr
2
. From DFT analysis of the degradation process of MAPbBr
3
, hydroxyl radicals and hydroxide ions from residual water in the UHV chamber were attributed responsibility for the degradation initiation;
(86,87)
the suggested complete degradation reaction cycle is shown in
Figure
9
e.

div.p:
Figure 9. Degradation of MAPbBr
3
in UHV conditions. Topography images of
in situ
cleaved MAPbBr
3
single crystal after (a) 7 and (b) 22 days in the UHV chamber. (b) Formation of a pit around the degraded clusters is indicated by a yellow line. (c) Change of the coverage of the degraded clusters over time in the UHV chamber. (d) Topography of a degraded cluster exhibiting hexagonal symmetry resembling the PbBr
2
crystalline structure. All scale bars are 200 nm. (e) Proposed degradation pathway in the presence of water vapor in the UHV chamber. Adapted with permission from ref
(145)
. Copyright 2019 Royal Society of Chemistry.

div.h2:
Operando
Surface Science on Nanoparticle Catalyst

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
TEM is a powerful imaging technique to investigate the structural and chemical properties of nanoparticles. Generally, TEM is operated in UHV (≈10
–9
mbar) conditions to protect the electron emission gun and to prevent the decline of spatial resolution of TEM by the inelastic collision between electrons and gas molecules. Despite the limitations, attempts for TEM observation in a more realistic reaction environment have continued, and its concept is represented by the schematic illustration in
Figure
10
a. In 1935, operating the TEM in a more realistic chemical reaction environment was proposed by Marton.
(148)
Since then, two types of methods for real-time observation in chemical reaction environments have been developed.
(149)
One approach utilizes E-TEM combined with differential pumping system (DPS), modifying the conventional UHV-TEM to set the environmental zone (E-zone) separately near the specimen stage.
(150−152)
Two additional apertures with DPS were installed above and below the E-zone to relieve the pressure gap between UHV and the ambient pressure for
in situ
observation. This system was designed for stably protecting the field emission gun (FEG) and preventing electron energy loss. The other method is using a specimen holder as a nanoreactor, which is a built-in window-closed environmental cell (E-cell) system based on micromechanical system (MEMS) technology.
(153−155)
Without any modifications of TEM, the window-closed E-cell system can be operated on a conventional UHV-TEM system.

div.p: Figure 10. Schematic illustrations of (a) E-TEM, (b) AP-XPS, (c) catalytic nanodiode, and (d) energy band diagram for detection of hot electrons on nanocatalysts.

div.div:
E-TEM observation using the DPS shows relatively high stability during the
operando
imaging process. Since the DPS is installed inside, the FEG can be protected and reliable images are obtained, because there are no extrinsic electron beam scattering factors without gas molecules and specimens in the imaging process. In this case, the E-TEM can be operated in gas conditions at ambient pressure (<20 mbar).
(156)
However, several drawbacks arise from the modification of conventional UHV-TEM. First of all, the conventional UHV-TEM modifying process is expensive. Then, there are functional problems related to competition over the limited internal space of the TEM column caused by the introduction of DPS. It causes the absence of a probe corrector inside the column and blocks the high-angle scattered electrons.
(155)
Then, the E-TEM finally exhibits slightly lower spatial resolution (
i.e.
, the weak intensity of electron beam) on scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM)-related micro/spectroscopies (
e.g.
, annular dark-field (ADF)-STEM imaging, electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis) than the conventional spherical aberration-corrected (Cs-corrected) TEM.

On the other hand, E-TEM observation with a window-closed E-cell can be operated without modification of conventional TEM. So, it is possible to obtain the STEM spectro-/microscopy investigations with a high spatial resolution by using Cs-corrected high-resolution STEM. Besides, it can perform experiments at even higher pressure (≈4 bar) than the operation with DPS, because it works in a small volume reaction cell closed by the window made of a membrane with high-pressure resistance.
(155)
However, using a window-closed E-cell as a nanoreactor requires several prerequisites for
operando
observation. The window should be made of a material which can be transmitted by the electron, can withstand the high pressure, and should have stability against the electron beam. If the leakage takes place on the window, the vacuum collapses in the TEM column, which can cause serious damage to the internal vacuum equipment (
e.g.
, FEG, imaging detectors, and vacuum pumps). In order to prevent this risk, silicon nitride (SiN) and carbon (C) membranes are mainly used as window materials of E-cell due to the high durability and gas pressure resistance.
(154,157)

Through the E-TEM observation, real-time structural changes by molecular interactions at gas–solid interface during the chemical reaction can be directly observed. Recently, many noteworthy studies dealing with physicochemical properties of nanoparticles have been reported
via
E-TEM investigations at various catalytic environments. Although the current E-TEM technology shows some technical limitations so far, it remains a promising essential characterization methodology for developing efficient industrial catalysts.

AP-XPS is also an important
in situ
surface-sensitive characterization technique for nanocatalysts to bridge the material gap between single crystal and nanoparticle catalysts under chemical reaction conditions. The development of synthesis methods of size- and shape-controlled nanoparticles and AP-XPS, shown in
Figure
10
b, give opportunities for investigating the surface of nanoparticles on the atomic level under catalytic reaction conditions.
(6,158,159)
One of the most prominent differences between AP-XPS measurement at the surface of single crystals and nanoparticles is in surface preparation methods. Since sputter–annealing preparation is not available, the surface of the nanoparticles can often be covered by carbonaceous capping layer residues from the sample preparation process, which is only removed at elevated temperature.
(160)
The surfaces of nanoparticles are often subject to segregation, reconstruction, and oxidative/reductive evolution during catalytic reaction, which are also deeply correlated to catalytic activity.
(76,77)
Therefore, in AP-XPS studies of catalytic nanoparticles, surface contaminants from the preparation, surface structural changes, and catalytic activity must be carefully considered in order to reveal the reaction mechanism of nanocatalysts.

It is challenging to observe the hot electron dynamics under surface chemical reactions on metal surfaces due to the quick relaxation of hot electrons. Therefore, it is essential to consider the question of how to measure excited hot charge carriers in metal catalyst surfaces by an exothermic catalytic reaction. A solution to this issue was found recently by Somorjai, who proposed the use of thin film-based Schottky nanodiodes, called “metal–semiconductor catalytic nanodiodes,” for detection of charge carriers in the surface chemical reactions.
(161)
These hot electron–hole pairs can be directly detected as an electric signal, called “chemicurrent.” Even though many experimental results have indicated that the metal–oxide interface plays an essential role in determining catalytic activity and selectivity, the origin of the metal–support interaction has not been demonstrated, due to the lack of appropriate surface science techniques of experimental measurement.
(162−164)
Therefore, metal–semiconductor catalytic nanodiodes have received significant attention as a proper measurement technique to conclude the argument, since it can simultaneously measure the transfer of excited charge carriers through the metal–semiconductor interfaces while taking measurements of turnover rate under catalytic reactions. The original analysis of hot charge carriers using these Schottky nanodiodes was applied to heterogeneous catalysis.
(165,166)

Most research studies of nonadiabatic surface chemical reactions using Schottky nanodiodes have used the hydrogen oxidation reaction,
(167−172)
since nonadiabatic electronic excitation (
i.e.
, excitation of electron–hole pairs) is more frequent when light molecules interact with metal catalyst surfaces.
(173−175)
And since most catalysts are complex systems that consist of metal nanoparticles 1–10 nm in size dispersed on a support, a modified hybrid nanodiode was demonstrated by Park
et al.
, where colloidal Pt nanoparticles of a defined size (
i.e.
, 1.7 and 4.5 nm) are deposited on an Au/TiO
2
Schottky nanodiode (see
Figure
10
c for schematic illustration of the catalytic nanodiode) as two-dimensional arrays to study the transfer of charge carriers across the metal–support interface in such systems.
(171)
Here, since the Au thin film, placed between the Pt nanoparticles and the TiO
2
substrate, is nonreactive and provides an electrical connection between the separated Pt nanoparticle arrays, the flux of hot electrons created on the Pt nanoparticles under H
2
oxidation reaction can be measured as a current signal across the Au/TiO
2
interface (
Figure
10
d).

Operando
microscopy technique provides extensive opportunities for understanding the molecular dynamics between adsorbate and catalyst. It brings not only structural changes of the catalyst during the gas–solid reaction but also a decisive clue for tracing catalytic reaction mechanisms along with spectroscopy analysis. Bimetallic nanocatalyst is a promising candidate as a heterogeneous catalyst, which also serves appropriate platforms to carry out the
in situ
investigation for catalysis using E-TEM. The bimetallic nanoparticles generate an atomic rearrangement at certain temperatures and chemical environments (
e.g.
, O
2
, H
2
, and CO).
(178−180)
There are some intuitive
in situ
E-TEM studies for atomic rearrangement in the bimetallic nanoparticles. Han
et al.
showed how the atomic arrangement occurs in a Ni
2
Co nanoparticle during an oxidation reaction with EELS mapping analysis, as shown in
Figure
11
a.
(176)
As the oxidation reaction progresses, the Ni and Co atoms inside the Ni–Co bimetal nanoparticle prefer to react with O
2
molecules, forming metal–oxide shells on the surface and cavities inside the metallic core simultaneously. It indicates that the core metallic atoms (Ni, Co) diffuse toward the oxide layer to react with oxygen, which is elucidated by the Kirkendall effect.
(181,182)

div.p:
Figure 11.
In situ
observation of bimetallic nanoparticle for surface evolution by atomic rearrangement and its role in the catalytic reaction. (a) Time-sequenced
in situ
ADF-STEM images of a Ni
2
Co nanoparticle and the corresponding EELS mapping of O, Co, and Ni elements during oxidation reaction (0.2 mbar of O
2
, 400 °C). Scale bar, 50 nm. Reprinted with permission under a Creative Commons CC-BY license from ref
(176)
. Copyright 2016 Springer Nature.
(176)
(b) Time-sequenced TEM images of Pt
0.5
Co
0.5
nanoparticle during oxidation reaction (0.1 mbar O
2
, 250 °C). (c) Plot for the perimeter to area ratio of rearranged CoO phase on the Pt
0.5
Co
0.5
nanoparticle over time. Adapted with permission from ref
(112)
. Copyright 2014 ACS.
(112)
(d) Before and (e) after
in situ
TEM images related to the formation of CoO on Pt–Co bimetallic nanoparticle during oxidation reaction (0.5 mbar O
2
, 125 °C). Scale bars, 5 nm (left) and 2 nm (right). Reproduced with permission under a Creative Commons CC-BY license from ref
(177)
. Copyright 2018 Springer Nature.

div.div:
Recently, Pt 3d transition metal (TM) bimetallic alloy (
e.g.
, Pt–Ni, Co, and Cu) has received intense attention as a heterogeneous catalyst. The Pt alloy with 3d TM exhibits the changed chemical property originated from a d-band center shift
(183,184)
and atomic rearrangement on the surface (noted by “surface restructuring”) in various adsorbates environments,
(178−180)
which is advantageous for enhancing the catalytic performance. Especially, the Pt 3d TM bimetallic alloy forms intermediate structures such as Pt–TM oxide interfacial structures on the topmost surface.
(114)
Xin
et al.
showed the real-time evolution of strained epitaxial CoO atomic structure on the Pt
0.5
Co
0.5
nanoparticle during the oxidation reaction using E-TEM.
(112)
From
Figure
11
b,c, we notice the detailed two-stage formation mechanism: (i) in the early stage, the conformal CoO film growth occurs by surface restructuring during the reaction with O
2
molecules, and then (ii) the growth aspect continuously changes the CoO island growth on the surface of the Pt–Co nanoparticle. The formation of epitaxial CoO islands induces the interfacial structures between Pt atoms and CoO islands on the surface of Pt–Co nanoparticles. Lee
et al.
suggested the role of Pt–CoO interfacial structures in Pt–Co bimetallic catalysts by hot electron detection during the hydrogen oxidation reaction.
(177)
The real-time formation of CoO in the Pt–Co nanocrystal system (
Figure
11
d,e), and its role and catalytic mechanism were unveiled by E-TEM investigation with XPS analysis and DFT calculations.

AP-XPS gives direct information on the chemical state and surface composition of the catalyst, including reactants, products, and intermediate species that can only be present under reaction conditions. This allows us to observe the reconstruction of surface and the catalytic active sites of nanoparticle catalysts during the catalytic reaction.
(74,76,185−190)

The active species on metal nanoparticles has been identified using AP-XPS. For example, Grass
et al.
revealed the reactive oxide on Rh nanoparticles by using AP-XPS under CO oxidation conditions.
(186)
They synthesized Rh nanoparticles with different sizes
via
the polyol reduction with poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) as a capping agent. Monolayer Rh nanoparticle films were prepared by the Langmuir–Blodgett method. The catalytic activity of Rh nanoparticle films for the CO oxidation was tested in a batch reactor under 20 Torr of CO, 50 Torr of O
2
, and balance He at 423–498 K. The 2 nm Rh nanoparticles show much higher TOF value with smaller activation energy than 7 nm Rh nanoparticles (
Figure
12
a). The AP-XPS spectra of Rh 3d were obtained under CO oxidation conditions for investigating the surface metal/oxide composition (
Figure
12
b). The spectra of Rh 3d showed that the smaller 2 nm Rh nanoparticles formed a thicker surface oxide than 7 nm Rh nanoparticles during the reaction at 423–473 K. It was concluded that the thick oxide shell of the smaller Rh nanoparticles gives strong catalytic enhancement for CO oxidation reaction. For Ru nanoparticles, it exhibits opposite catalytic properties compared to Rh nanoparticles under CO oxidation condition.
(191,187)
Panels c and d of
Figure
12
show the TEM images of 2.8 and 6 nm Ru nanoparticles, respectively.
Figure
12
e is the schematic representation of the
[email protected]
structure of 2.8 and 6 nm Ru nanoparticles with a RuO
2
surface oxide layer. Qadir
et al.
calculated the RuO
2
/Ru ratios under CO oxidation conditions (
Figure
12
f) from the AP-XPS spectra of Ru 3p (
Figure
12
g). The AP-XPS spectra of Ru 3p for 6 and 2.8 nm Ru nanoparticles show that the Ru nanoparticles were oxidized to RuO
2
at the surface as the temperature increased under CO oxidation condition (80 mTorr of CO and 200 mTorr of O
2
). The thickness of RuO
2
layer for 2.8 nm Ru nanoparticles is larger than that of 6 nm Ru nanoparticles. Thus, ultrathin surface oxide of
[email protected]
RuO
2
is more stable with the larger size nanoparticles, resulting in enhanced catalytic activity for CO oxidation.

div.p:
Figure 12. AP-XPS studies on Rh, Ru nanoparticles, and Co–Pd bimetallic nanoparticles for CO oxidation. (a) Turnover frequency (TOF) at 200 °C and activation energy of Rh nanoparticles for CO oxidation under the 20 Torr of CO and 50 Torr of O
2
at 150–225 °C. (b) AP-XPS spectra of the Rh 3d
5/2
for 7 and 2 nm Rh nanoparticles under 200 mTorr of CO and 500 mTorr og O
2
at 150 and 200 °C. Adapted with permission from ref
(186)
. Copyright 2008 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim. TEM images of (c) 2.8 and (d) 6 nm Ru nanoparticles. Reprinted with permission from ref
(191)
. Copyright 2010 American Chemical Society. (e)
[email protected]
structure of 2.8 and 6 nm Ru nanoparticles having a RuO
2
surface oxide layer. (f) RuO
2
/Ru ratios under CO oxidation conditions as calculated from AP-XPS spectra of Ru 3p. (g) AP-XPS spectra of the Ru 3p for 6 and 2.8 nm Ru nanoparticles under CO oxidation condition (80 mTorr of CO and 200 mTorr of O
2
) with increasing temperature. Reprinted with permission from ref
(187)
. Copyright 2012 American Chemical Society. (h) Catalytic activity of Pd and Co–Pd bimetallic nanoparticles with different elemental composition for CO oxidation. (i) AP-XPS spectra of Pd 3d for Co
0.24
Pd
0.76
exposed to 100 mTorr of CO, O
2
or mixed gas of CO and O
2
at the different temperatures. Blue spectra were CO-only or CO-rich (4:1 CO:O
2
) and red spectra were O
2
-only or O
2
-rich (1:4 CO:O
2
). Adapted with permission from ref
(188)
. Copyright 2019 Springer Nature.

div.div:
Bimetallic alloy nanoparticles have also been progressively studied after the development of
in situ operando
surface characterization techniques. The structure of bimetallic nanoparticles is easily changed by segregation, reconstruction, and oxidative/reductive evolution during reaction conditions, which affect the activity and stability of the catalysts.
(76,77)
Wu
et al.
reported the formation of CoO
x
at the surface of Co–Pd bimetallic nanoparticles, inducing synergistic effects between Pd and CoO
x
by using AP-XPS and
in situ
and
ex situ
TEM under gas conditions.
(188)
They synthesized monodispersed Co–Pd bimetallic nanoparticles with different compositions, using oleylamine as a capping agent. Catalytic properties of Co–Pd alloy nanoparticles were tested in the flow reactor after H
2
pretreatment for activating catalysts. The Co
0.24
Pd
0.76
nanoparticles exhibited the highest catalytic activity (
Figure
12
h). The AP-XPS spectra of Pd 3d were obtained under CO-rich or O
2
-rich conditions for investigating surface reconstruction (
Figure
12
i). At 300 °C, the reversible intensity variation was observed under CO and O
2
conditions, evidence of reversible surface segregation. The surface composition was calculated from the AP-XPS spectra of Co 3p and Pd 4p and was correlated with the catalytic activity. They found that the CoO
x
is generated at the surface of Co–Pd nanoparticles by segregation of Co under reaction conditions, and the coexistence of Pd and CoO
x
at the surface gives the catalytic enhancement of the bimetallic nanoparticle catalysts.

div.h3: Revealing Catalytic Activity and Charge Flow with Catalytic Nanodiodes
div.div:
Understanding fundamental mechanisms of energy conversion and dissipation at solid–gas or solid–liquid interfaces are crucial issues for the field of heterogeneous catalysis. Thus, investigation of charge transfer on metal–oxide interfaces under the elementary surface chemical reactions is of great importance in surface chemistry. Here, in a Au/TiO
2
Schottky nanodiode, a current signal corresponding to the hot electron transfer generated during the H
2
oxidation reaction in an H
2
(15 Torr) + O
2
(745 Torr) gas mixture both on 1.7 and 4.5 nm Pt nanoparticles/Au/TiO
2
nanodiodes is shown in
Figure
13
a. The chemicurrent signal shows a clear temperature dependence caused by enhanced activity of H
2
oxidation on the Pt catalyst at the increased reaction temperature. Also, it was demonstrated that the magnitude of the chemicurrent is dependent on the size of the Pt nanoparticles, due to the change in reactivity. The flow of hot electrons measured from 1.7 nm Pt nanoparticles presents a significantly increased signal compared with 4.5 nm Pt nanoparticles in H
2
oxidation, because of the enhanced reactivity of the smaller Pt nanoparticles. This result clarifies a decreased tendency for the chemicurrent as the size of the Pt nanoparticles increases, which can be attributed to attenuation of the hot electrons resulting in a decrease in catalytic activity. In addition, the chemicurrent value is also dependent on the thickness of the Au film. As can be seen, an increase in the thickness of Au film results in a significant decline in the current signal, which is associated with the shorter travel length for the hot electrons, compared with their inelastic mean free path.

div.p:
Figure 13. (a) Size effect of Pt nanoparticles on hot electrons proved by temperature dependence of the current signal excited by catalytic H
2
oxidation and pure O
2
condition on Au/TiO
2
Schottky nanodiodes with various thicknesses of Au film.
(171)
(b) Potential barrier heights at the different interfaces between the Pt catalysts and supports obtained from Arrhenius plots for chemicurrent signal. The potential barrier height of the 4.5 nm Pt nanoparticles/graphene/TiO
2
catalytic nanodiode is lower than that of the 4.5 nm Pt nanoparticles/Au/TiO
2
catalytic nanodiode, which is close to that of the 4 nm Pt thin film/Au/TiO
2
catalytic nanodiode.
(172)
(c) Schematic of a Pt–Co bimetallic nanoparticles/Au/TiO
2
catalytic nanodiode and cross-sectional field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) image of a 10 nm Au film on a 250 nm TiO
2
layer. (d) Plot of the chemicurrent yield as a function of the Co fraction under H
2
oxidation at different reaction temperatures. Panel c reprinted and panel d adapted with permission under a Creative Commons CC-BY license from ref
(177)
. Copyright 2018 Springer Nature. (e) Schematic illustration of the Co
3
O
4
nanoparticles/Pt film/TiO
2
catalytic nanodiode. The rectifying junction can form at the interface between the Pt film and TiO
2
. (f) Chemicurrent yield from the Pt film/TiO
2
and Co
3
O
4
nanoparticles/Pt film/TiO
2
nanodiodes under the H
2
oxidation reaction.
(192)

div.div:
As previously shown,
(173,193,194)
the chemicurrent is proportional to the reaction rate. Thus, we can express the dependence of the chemicurrent generated on the catalytic nanodiodes on the TOF during an exothermic chemical reaction, according to
eq 2
.
(2)
where α is the chemicurrent yield,
q
is the elementary charge,
A
is the active area of the catalyst,
N
Pt
is the number of Pt sites per mm
2
, and TOF is the reaction rate. Here, we can estimate the chemicurrent yield, which is the number of hot electrons detected per single chemical reaction on the nanodiode surface (
i.e.
, the efficiency of hot electron excitation on the metal catalyst surface). For the case of the planar Schottky nanodiode (
i.e.
, 4 nm Pt film/Au/TiO
2
nanodiode), the chemicurrent plotted
versus
the TOF is a straight line, which gives α = 3 × 10
–4
showing identical activation energies for both the TOF and the chemicurrent, which is in good agreement with estimates done in other, similar experiments.
(167,173,194,195)
However, for Pt nanoparticles/Au/TiO
2
nanodiodes, it was shown that the activation energy obtained from chemicurrent could be significantly larger than that determined from TOF, and this feature is slightly different from the results from thin film diodes, indicating that the capping layer existing on the Pt nanoparticles causes an additional potential barrier for the transport of electrons.
(195)
Then, we found that such dependence can be fitted to
eq 2
by taking the α as a temperature-dependent function [
eq 3
]:
(3)
where Φ is a parameter similar in meaning to the activation barrier. Fitting the chemicurrent measured on the Au/TiO
2
nanodiodes with Pt nanoparticles to
eq 2
, in which the chemicurrent yield calculated according to
eq 3
is substituted, gives Φ = 9.34 kcal mol
–1
for the 4.5 nm Pt nanoparticles. This potential barrier can allow one to explain the difference in activation energy based on the chemicurrent and TOF measurements. Furthermore, to study the chemicurrent effect on Pt nanoparticles supported on a graphene layer, since graphene has several extraordinary properties that make it a promising candidate for use as a support,
(168,196)
Lee
et al.
developed a graphene-based catalytic nanodiode (
i.e.
, Pt nanoparticles/graphene/TiO
2
catalytic nanodiode) where a single graphene layer deposited on a TiO
2
film is used instead of a gold thin film for the electrical connection with the separated Pt nanoparticle arrays.
(172)
When the flow of hot electrons excited from Pt nanoparticles was detected using a graphene-based catalytic nanodiode under identical H
2
oxidation reaction, it was observed that the efficiency for hot electron detection was significantly enhanced because of the facilitating transport of electrons with improving reactivity.
(168)
Therefore, as shown in
Figure
13
b, the calculated potential barrier at the Pt nanoparticles/graphene interface is significantly smaller than that for the Pt nanoparticles–Au interface, indicating that the utilization of a single graphene layer can significantly accelerate the electron transfer through the metal nanoparticle–support interface.

Unlike conventional monometallic nanoparticles, bimetallic nanoparticles have attracted great attention in the heterogeneous catalysis field, since bimetal can control the binding energy and electronic structure in catalysts, resulting in unpredictable catalytic activity.
(111,197)
The formation of oxide–metal interfacial sites on bimetallic nanoparticles by surface segregation under reaction were specifically claimed to be responsible for enhanced catalytic performance.
(198)
Recently, Lee
et al.
reported the real-time detection of hot electrons excited on bimetallic Pt–Co nanoparticles during exothermic H
2
oxidation reaction to find the fundamental role of oxide–metal interfaces.
(177)
Here, we fabricated catalytic nanoparticles/Au/TiO
2
nanodiodes with stoichiometric Pt–Co nanoparticles prepared through the co-reduction method using two metal precursors. As shown in
Figure
13
c, catalytically active nanoparticles were deposited onto the Au/TiO
2
nanodiodes as a two-dimensional array using the Langmuir–Blodgett technique, in order to investigate the dynamics of hot electrons on bimetallic Pt–Co nanocatalysts. In both turnover rate and chemicurrent signal measurements, we investigated that the activity of the bimetallic Pt–Co nanoparticles is significantly increased compared with monometallic nanoparticles (
i.e.
, Pt or Co nanoparticles). Then, we estimated the chemicurrent yield as shown in
Figure
13
d; the highest yield was obtained from Pt
3
Co
1
nanoparticles with the highest CoO/Pt interfacial area, proving that the modified electronic structure at the oxide–metal interfacial sites played an important role in boosting the catalytic activity of the bimetallic Pt–Co nanoparticles. From DFT calculations to compare reaction pathways of H
2
oxidation both on the Pt(111) surface and at the CoO–Pt interface, we also demonstrated that the reduced barrier for formation of OH at the metal–oxide interfacial sites can promote the overall catalytic performance of H
2
oxidation reaction. Therefore, on the basis of both the turnover rate and chemicurrent results, we can conclude that the synergistic catalytic activity of the bimetallic Pt–Co nanoparticles came from the formation of the CoO–Pt interface under surface chemical reaction environments. Furthermore, for understanding hot electron dynamics at inverse oxide/metal interfacial sites, Lee
et al.
fabricated a Schottky nanodevice by depositing Co
3
O
4
nanoparticles on a Pt film/TiO
2
nanodiode forming nanoscale inverse oxide–metal interfaces (
Figure
13
e).
(192)
Similar to the previous study, both the chemicurrent and catalytic activity were enhanced at the inverse CoO–Pt interfaces under the H
2
oxidation reaction. To demonstrate the electronic features on the inverse oxide/metal interface, the chemicurrent yield was estimated both on Pt/TiO
2
nanodiode and Co
3
O
4
nanoparticles/Pt/TiO
2
nanodiode, as shown in
Figure
13
f. The calculated chemicurrent yield was significantly improved in the Co
3
O
4
nanoparticles/Pt film, leading to the conclusion that electronic perturbation on inverse oxide/metal interfaces not only promotes the excitation of hot electrons but enhances catalytic performance. Overall, real-time detection of hot electrons using Schottky nanodiodes demonstrates the mechanism at metal–oxide interfaces on heterogeneous catalysis and monitors the catalytic performances; it can thereby be a useful
operando
probe for approaching the materials and pressure gaps.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We have outlined the recent studies on fundamental atomic and molecular aspects of chemical reactions in complicated and realistic systems, which is a drastic transformation from the idealized model systems used in the past. We have demonstrated that various
operando
surface analyses can give crucial information about surface restructuring, change of oxidation states, chemical bonds, and the formation of intermediate species on catalytic surfaces.
Table
1
summarizes the features of the
operando
surface science techniques, including operating conditions, information probed, and limitations.

Table 1. Summary of
Operando
Surface Science Techniques for Chemical Reactions

operates in contact mode; able to probe semiconducting and insulating surfaces
lacks true atomic resolution imaging; local probe; image drift
elemental composition, oxidation, and chemical state
differentially pumped electrostatic lens system; available with synchrotron radiation source
macroscopic averaging effect; easily disturbed by surface contaminants and charging
for single crystal and well-defined surface
high vacuum to 1.33 bar (KBr window) or to 15 bar (ZnSe window)

div.div:
The field of
operando
surface science has broad applications for energy and the environment, and it has advanced significantly due to recent developments in instrumentation, but challenges remain. We outline four major challenges and the future research directions that we envision (
Figure
14
).

div.p:
Figure 14. Future prospects of
operando
surface sciences on solid–gas and solid–liquid interfaces that have an impact in heterogeneous catalysis, photocatalysis, self-cleaning, electrochemistry, and solar energy conversion.

div.h3: Heterogenous Catalysis and the Smart Design of Catalytic Materials
div.div:
Single crystal metal surfaces have been useful model systems in elucidating the role of surface defects, such as steps and kinks, and the mobility of reaction intermediates in catalytic reactivity and selectivity. The use of single crystals as model catalytic systems has shed light on many surface phenomena, which, in turn, has helped in the choice of metallic clusters for use in industrial catalysis. Industrial catalysts, however, do not consist solely of metal but are made up of metal particles in the 1–100 nm size regime dispersed in a high surface area support. They are produced by synthesizing the metal particles and support separately and then dispersing the metal clusters onto the support using various techniques (
e.g.
, wet-impregnation, coprecipitation, or ion exchange). Surface science studies on single crystal surfaces under ambient pressure have revealed the nature of reactive sites. This information can be used to design the advance catalytic materials with tunable size and compositions.
(201)
Various catalyst architectures, including
[email protected]
, York/shell, hybrid, and single atom catalysts (SACs), have been demonstrated.
(202−204)
SACs, with the advantages of
in situ operando
surface probing techniques, are especially emerging as a model system in elucidating catalytic reaction mechanisms and the dynamic behaviors of catalytic sites at the atomic resolution, enabling the investigation of microenvironment–activity relationships and the underlying reaction mechanisms of various electrochemical energy conversion reactions.
(205−209)
Defect engineering and metal support interactions are extremely important concepts in catalytic application.
(210)
The concepts and knowledge obtained by
operando
surface analysis can be used to develop catalytic materials with better catalytic performances, including high activity, selectivity, and stability, with an impact on industrial catalysis.

Hydrophobicity or wetting behavior are an important subject in the surface science community, due to its relevance to self-cleaning and photocatalysis. For example, TiO
2
, well-known nontoxic and abundant materials have interesting self-cleaning properties, due to photocatalytic properties combined with ultraviolet treatment to reach a superhydrophilic state (attracting water) or with a hydrophobic self-assembled monolayer to obtain superhydrophobicity (repelling water). The origin of TiO
2
’s wetting behavior has been intensively investigated in the surface science community.
(131,211,212)
Operando
surface analysis can be performed on model systems, including single crystal, thin film, and nanoparticles, to revisit the issue of hydrophobicity under more realistic conditions. This will give rise to the atomic-scale understanding on the origin of self-cleaning and photocatalysis.

Operando
surface investigation on solid–liquid interfaces has received great attention, due to its relevance in electrochemistry and batteries. However, complexities associated with van der Waals hydrogen bonds interacting with the solid substrate, as well as intermolecular and intramolecular interactions in liquid, makes the atomic-scale understanding of electrochemical processes challenging. In order to shed further light on our fundamental understanding of structural and dynamical properties at the interface,
operando
experimental investigations combining the electrochemical measurements are carried out.
(213)
Various
in situ
techniques including STM,
(214)
XPS,
(215)
X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS),
(216−218)
FTIR,
(219)
and hot electron detection
(200)
have been utilized to elucidate the atomic-scale origin of the chemical processes occurring at solid–liquid interfaces. The breakthrough in this direction will give rise to the molecular-level understanding of electrochemical reaction processes and reveal the physical and chemical processes taking place on battery electrodes.

div.h3: Charge Transfer and Solar Energy Conversion
div.div:
Operando
surface science can also play a crucial role in the research of solar energy conversion. Quantitative characterization of charge transfer between the light absorber and the electrodes that transmit the generated charges has been important issues in photovoltaics. These charge transport processes depend on environmental conditions, including gas, pressure, and temperature. Therefore, the atomic-scale characterization of the degradation mechanisms of the light absorber remains a challenging issue, because of the difficulty in obtaining good model systems and surface-sensitive techniques with environmental control. In addition, the photon-generated charge is strongly affected by the non-uniform distribution of the electrical field of the localized surface plasmon, and
operando
surface techniques can be utilized to elucidate this aspect on the surface plasmon-driven photoelectron generation.
(220)

The frontiers of molecular surface science move from UHV surface studies of single crystals to high-pressure gas and solid–liquid interfaces to nanocrystals and nanocomposites, which are more relevant to industrial chemical processes.
Operando
surface characterization on various model systems will give rise to a broader understanding of atomic and molecular processes while the catalysts work and thereby build a foundation for synthesizing highly efficient nanocatalysts with desired structures and properties.

A review with 18 refs. Modern surface physics is transforming the black art of catalysis, revealing a fascinating choreog. followed by reacting atoms and mols. The investigation of transition metal oxide surfaces is a very active field today and has implications that also reach into other fields such as sensors and high-temp. superconductors. Our ability to study catalytic reactions by prepg. model systems and understanding them in detail depends upon our increasing knowledge of the physics of compd. surfaces. There are lots of opportunities for fruitful interactions between physicists and chemists in a field that has never been more lively.

A review with 237 refs. Metal oxide interfaces, metal coatings or dispersed metals on oxide supports play an important part in many technol. areas. Nevertheless, there is still a lack of fundamental knowledge about the essential properties of thin metal films and small metal particles on oxide supports, although a deeper understanding could help to improve the electronic, mech. or catalytic performance of such systems. In the past, a no. of different approaches are proposed and explored aiming at the prepn. of suitable model systems. In this review, the authors discuss the possibility to use thin, well-ordered oxide films as supports for the study of deposited metal particles. This approach offers the advantage to permit the unrestricted application of all exptl. methods, which rely on a good elec. or thermal cond. of the sample, like PES, LEED, STM or TDS. With the help of several examples taken from the authors' own work on a thin alumina film, it is feasible to characterize such systems on a microscopic level with respect to all relevant structural, electronic and adsorption properties. In this way, correlations between these features can be established helping to understand the particular chem. and physics of small metal aggregates.

A review with 199 refs.; models of supported metal catalysts have been prepd. by deposition of transition metal vapor onto thin, well-ordered oxide layers, particularly alumina. The av. sizes of the metal particles and their size distributions are detd. by nucleation and growth. Here, we review the morphol. and structure of the oxide layers and the metal particles dispersed on them, as measured with a variety of methods including LEED and scanning tunneling microscopy. Electronic and magnetic structure as a function of particle size, adsorption properties, as well as reactivity with varying particle size are reviewed. The electronic structure of supported palladium particles has been studied and indicates that a nonmetal to metal transition occurs for particles exceeding 70-80 atoms per aggregate. Adsorption of CO has been studied in detail by Fourier transform IR spectroscopy. Interesting variations in the spectra when very small particles consisting of only a few metal atoms are investigated compared with larger particles and single-crystal surfaces are obsd. CO dissocn. has been studied on rhodium aggregates and a maximal dissocn. rate has been found for aggregates contg. several hundred metal atoms. The presence of defects on the particles is deduced to be origin of this behavior. (c) 2000 Academic Press.

High-Pressure CO Oxidation on Pt(111) Monitored with Infrared-Visible Sum Frequency Generation (SFG)
Su, Xingcai; Cremer, Paul S.; Shen, Y. Ron; Somorjai, Gabor A.

Catalytic CO oxidn. on Pt(111) to CO2 was studied under atm. pressures of CO and O2 and at various temps. Surface vibrational spectroscopy by sum frequency generation was used to probe the surface species, while the reaction rate and gas compn. were simultaneously monitored by gas chromatog. Correlation between the turnover rates and the surface coverage of various CO species were utilized to identify the active CO species in the reaction. Ignition, above which the reaction becomes self-sustained, divides the reaction into two reactivity regimes. Below ignition, atop bonded CO appears as the major species on the surface, but the reaction rate is inversely proportional to the surface coverage of this species, indicating that it is not the active species but rather an inhibitor. The obsd. activation energy for the reaction in this regime suggests that desorption of atop CO is the rate-limiting step in the reaction. Above ignition, the atop CO becomes hardly detectable and the activation energy reduces to the one directly assocd. with the reaction energy barrier between adsorbed CO and O on Pt. In all cases, the reaction rate is linearly proportional to the surface coverage of CO adsorbed at non-registry sites or defect (or distorted) surface sites. They are therefore identified as the active CO species in this surface catalytic reaction.
